Î‘á½Î¾Î¬Î½Î·Ï„Îµ\f + \fr 3:18 \ft Î±Ï…Î¾Î±Î½Î·Ï„Îµ \+bd f\+bd*\+sup 35\+sup* [27%] Â¦ Î±Ï…Î¾Î±Î½ÎµÏ„Îµ â„µA,B [60%] RP,HF,OC,TR,CP,NU Â¦ Î±Ï…Î¾Î±Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¸Îµ ğ•»\+sup 72\+sup*C [5%] Â¦ Î±Ï…Î¾Î±Î½Î·ÏƒÎ¸Îµ [3%] Â¦ Î±Ï…Î¾Î±Î½Î¿Î¹Ï„Îµ [5%] (Imperative or Subjunctive? I take it that Peter is offering a gentler alternative to falling from their steadfastness; render â€œrather, may you grow in grace â€¦â€)\f* \w Î´á½²|strong="G1161"\w* \w á¼Î½|strong="G1722"\w* \w Ï‡Î¬ÏÎ¹Ï„Î¹|strong="G5485"\w* \w ÎºÎ±á½¶|strong="G2532"\w* \w Î³Î½ÏÏƒÎµÎ¹|strong="G1108"\w* \w Ï„Î¿á¿¦|strong="G3588"\w* \w ÎšÏ…ÏÎ¯Î¿Ï…|strong="G2962"\w* \w á¼¡Î¼á¿¶Î½|strong="G1473"\w* \w ÎºÎ±á½¶|strong="G2532"\w* \w Î£Ï‰Ï„á¿†ÏÎ¿Ï‚|strong="G4990"\w* \w á¼¸Î·ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦|strong="G2424"\w* \w Î§ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿á¿¦|strong="G5547"\w*. \w Î‘á½Ï„á¿·|strong="G0846"\w* \w á¼¡|strong="G3588"\w* \w Î´ÏŒÎ¾Î±|strong="G1391"\w* \w ÎºÎ±á½¶|strong="G2532"\w* \w Î½á¿¦Î½|strong="G3568"\w* \w ÎºÎ±á½¶|strong="G2532"\w* \w Îµá¼°Ï‚|strong="G1519"\w* \w á¼¡Î¼Î­ÏÎ±Î½|strong="G2250"\w* \w Î±á¼°á¿¶Î½Î¿Ï‚|strong="G0165"\w*. \w á¼ˆÎ¼Î®Î½|strong="G0281"\w*.\f + \fr 3:18 \ft Î±Î¼Î·Î½ \+bd f\+bd*\+sup 35\+sup* ğ•»\+sup 72\+sup*â„µA,C (97.4%) RP,HF,OC,TR,CP[NU] Â¦ â€” B (2.6%) \+it ECM\+it*\f*\sup ,\sup*\f + \fr 3:18 \ft The citation of \+bd f\+bd*\+sup 35\+sup* is based on forty-three MSSâ€”18, 35, 141, 149, 201, 204, 328, 386, 394, 432, 604, 664, 757, 824, 928, 986, 1072, 1075, 1100, 1248, 1249, 1503, 1548, 1637, 1725, 1732, 1754, 1761, 1768, 1855, 1864, 1865, 1876, 1892, 1897, 2221, 2352, 2431, 2466, 2554, 2587, 2626 and 2723â€”all of which I collated myself. 35, 1725, 1864, 2554 and 2723 are very pure representatives of \+bd f\+bd*\+sup 35\+sup* in 2 Peter, with not a single variant, and so for the exemplars of 18, 141, 824, 1072, 1075, 1503, 1865 and 1897. For 35, 1725, 1864, 2554 and 2723 to have no variants after all the centuries of transmission is surely an eloquent demonstration of the faithfulness and accuracy of that transmission. Since these MSS come from all over the Mediterranean world (Sinai, Jerusalem, Patmos, Constantinople, Bucharest, Aegean, Trikala, Athens, Meteora, Sparta, Ochrida, Mt. Athos [nine different monasteries], Grottaferrata, Vatican, etc.) they are certainly representative of the family, giving us the precise family profileâ€”it is reflected in the Text without exception. \+it ECM\+it* collated 127 continuous text manuscripts (MSS) for 2 Peter, apart from a few fragments, which number represents about 20% of the extant (known) MSS. By a careful comparison of \+it TuT\+it* and \+it ECM\+it* I believe we can arrive at some reasonably close extrapolations. Thus I venture to predict, if complete collations ever become available, that for any non-Byzantine variants listed with 5 to 1% support (in my apparatus) the margin of error should not exceed Â±1%; for non-Byzantine variants listed with 10 to 6% support the margin of error will hardly exceed Â±2%; where there is some division among the Byzantine witnesses the margin of error will rarely exceed Â±10%. However, I guarantee the witness of Family 35. Please see the last footnote for Matthew for further information.\f*
